segments.name: Phase II
segments.description: (Exact path TBA) Funded by a $2.99 million grant from Illinois Transportation Enhancement Program with 100% local match. Will run from Foley and Wesley to 52nd Street.
Algonquin has been awarded a $1.2 million grant from Illinois Transportation Enhancement Program with 100% local match to construct a 1.16-mile path from south of Teri Lane to Route 62.

segments.name: Ridgeland Avenue to Central Avenue
segments.description: The Illinois Transportation Enhancement Program has awarded the city of Oak Forest, Illinois a grant for $2.3 million with 50% local match to implement a 1.1-mile multi-use path along 151st street.

segments.name: E 110th Street to E 112th Street
segments.description: This is where the crosswalks start...

segments.name: E 112th Street to
segments.description: UNFINISHED

segments.name: Stillwell Drive to Des Plaines River Road
segments.description: The Illinois Transportation Enhancement Program has awarded the city of Des Plaines, Illinois a $1.2 million grant with 50% local match to implement a 0.5-mile multi-use path along Devon Avenue.

segments.name: Montrose to Belmont
segments.description: For some reason the official map doesn't include the part of this trail south of Addison. Did they just forget? It's clearly marked for bicycles.

segments.name: Devon to Argyle, East of the river
segments.description: Paved and painted bicycle trail. Includes underpasses beneath W Foster Ave, W Bryn Mawr Ave, W Peterson Ave (US Route 14), and N Lincoln Ave (US Route 41).

segments.name: Albany to Argyle, West of the river
Argyle to Lawrence, West of the river
segments.description: UNFINISHED; Trail continues to Carlisle, with bridge to Albany/Winona

segments.name: Francisco to Argyle, East of the river

segments.description: Length (miles): 1.02. Connects directly to the Skokie Line Trail.

segments.name: Weber Spur Trail Connection
segments.description: Connection between Valley Line Trail (Skokie Line Trail) and Weber Spur Trail

This does not appear on Chicago's official map, because it is not finished yet and remains partially gravel. CDOT is waiting on IDOT approval to move forward with the project and are hoping for paving to start in the next few years.
Trail through Labagh Woods, no Google Streetview available (UNFINISHED; CONTINUES OFF OF FOREST GLEN AVE)

segments.name: Jewel-Osco parking lot cutthrough
segments.description: This isn't a trail, but you can cut through the back of the parking lot to get to another chunk of the trail. It's paved and generally empty. Go onto the sidewalk behind the Marshall's to reach the chunk of North Branch Trail to the south.

segments.name: West of Eugene Field Park (N Loop)
segments.description: Paved but not painted for bikes

segments.name: West of Eugene Field Park (S Loop)
segments.description: Paved but not painted for bikes

segments.name: West of Eugene Field Park
segments.description: Paved but not painted for bikes

segments.name: Eugene Park, Albany Park Theater Connection
Eugene Park, to Foster Ave
segments.description: Paved, but not delineated - watch for pedestrians
Connects to Weber Spur Trail

segments.name: Southern segment - Oakton to Valley Line Trail
segments.description: Extends from the entrance to the Valley Line Trail up to Oakton St (you'll have to walk your bike along the sidewalk at Oakton to reach the northern segment).

segments.name: Northern segment - Main to Oakton
segments.description: Extends south from Main Street in Skokie, to the entrance of the Valley Line Trail at Chicago's city limits.
Elevated trail from Ridgeland to Ashland

Bloomingdale Trail Extension

Estimated Project Timeline:

- Phase I (Preliminary Engineering): Ongoing
- Phase II (Detailed Engineering): Q1 2026 to Q2 2027
- Phase III (Construction): Q4 2027 to Q4 2028
Multi-use trail along the lakefront
Pedestrian and bicycle bridge across Lake Shore Drive and Metra tracks. Connects to Lakefront Trail.
This is honestly more of a protected bike lane than a trail, but I suppose it is rather scenic so I will leave the official designation in place.
Includes a ped/bike bridge over 83rd Street

segments.name: S Union Ave to W 122nd Street
W 127th Street to Whistler Woods Forest Preserve

name: Chicago Riverwalk
description: Leaving this off the map. The space provided is not sufficient for biking, as it is often crowded with people walking.

segments.name: Central Park Ave to Homan Ave
Washington Park
segments.reason: I haven't been able to confirm that this was completed, or that protection was implemented along the entire marked route. Once I see it for myself, I will update this.

segments.name: Major Taylor Trail to Union Ave
S Ashland to Major Taylor Trail

name: Archer Avenue Protected Bike Lane
description:
Construction Update (12/25/2025)

- Concrete & asphalt work: Complete
- Pavement Striping: Anticipated completion by first week of January
- Precast Concrete Curbs for Bike Lanes: Anticipated completion by second week of January
- Signs & Flexible Delineators: Anticipated to begin the last week of December. Anticipated duration of 2-3 weeks.
- Impact Attenuator installation at viaduct south of W 31st Street: Scheduled installation around mid-January 2026.

segments.description: Parking-protected, with flexpost bumpouts at intersections for pedestrians. At least they didn't cut away for shared right turn lanes. Just watch out for cars pulling out of alleys.

segments.name: Valley Line Trail to North Shore Trail
Milwaukee to Kimball
segments.description:
From the project website:

"CDOT is partnering with Ward 30 and Ward 35 to implement Complete Streets safety improvements on Belmont Avenue between Kimball Avenue and Milwaukee Avenue as part of planned street resurfacing. This project will include bike, pedestrian, and transit upgrades and would be installed in 2024."

Was this finished? I have no idea. It said it would be done by the end of 2024. I need to check on this.

segments.name: Kimball to Western
segments.description: Some concrete, mostly parking-protected.

segments.name: Roosevelt to 18th Street
segments.description: Flexposts and curbs and parking

segments.name: Harrison to Roosevelt
segments.description: This is pretty bad... this is just flexposts and parking, and most of the flexposts are already flattened.

segments.name: Franklin to Madison
segments.description:
From the project website:

"CDOT will implement protected bike lanes on Central Park between Madison and Franklin Blvd. Additionally, increased pedestrian refuge space will be installed at the main entrance to the Garfield Park Conservatory. The new protected bike lanes will connect to existing protected bike lanes on Franklin Blvd. and Lake Street providing a comfortable route for biking to the Garfield Park Conservatory, Field House, and Park Space. The new protected bike lane is part of a growing network of bike infrastructure in the Garfield Park and Austin neighborhoods."

segments.name: Davis to Sheridan
segments.description: A truly world-class two-way cycletrack, with protected intersections and bus stop bypasses. Maybe it's because Evanston is a college town, but their engineers really knocked it out of the park with this one.

segments.name: Howard to Davis
segments.description: The Illinois Transportation Enhancement Program has awarded the city of Evanston, Illinois a $3 million grant with 100% local match in order to implement a two-way protected cycle track along Chicago Avenue, from the border with Chicago on Howard up to the intersection with Davis.

segments.name: Montrose to Winnemac
segments.description: From project website: 'Street improvements are coming to Clark Street between Montrose to Winnemac. These changes will make the street more comfortable for everyone - whether they walk, drive, bike, or take transit - and improve access to local businesses.'
Two-way cycle track on the eastern side of Clinton, parking-protected + flex posts + green paint.

segments.name: E 90th Street to E 92nd Street
segments.description:
This might be the most gorgeous protected bike lane I've seen in Chicago. Bus bumpouts, fresh green paint, concrete elevated paths - this bike lane is a model that all streets should follow. No idea why it's all the way out here.

The official Chicago government map also mislabels this bike lane as going all the way to South Chicago Ave - this is incorrect. The bike lane ends at 92nd street. Another example of the official map trying to pad its own numbers.

Not even Google Maps has this listed on their bike path layer - but you can see it in Streetview.

segments.name: Clybourn to Elston
segments.description: This is an older one, and the northern section is not very good - pretty much just flexposts, and most of the posts are already flattened.

segments.name: 14th to 17th Street
segments.description: Underpass beneath Metra BNSF railyard. Composed of jersey barriers.
Two-way cycle track on the western side of Dearborn, concrete + paint.
One-way cycle tracks in each direction. Existed pre-2016, was improved with yellow posts and concrete barriers in 2023.

segments.name: Magnolia to Stockton
segments.description:
• 20mph speed limit
  • Speed humps
  • Curb extensions
  • Raised crosswalks
  • Painted contraflow bike lane

segments.name: Grand to Kedzie
segments.description: Originally this was supposed to be completed alongside the Kedzie to California section. Delayed due to pushback from the alderwoman and certain community members.

links.name: Project Website, Complete Streets safety improvements for Division Street
Project Website, Complete Streets safety improvements for Division Street

segments.name: Ridgeway to Douglas Park (North side, westbound)
Ridgeway to Douglas Park (South side, eastbound)
Central to Long Avenue
segments.description:
Only partialy protected. Barriers have big gaps because of bus stops. If I was in charge, I'd narrow out the center median and put in bus boarding islands so that the bike lane can run behind them. But, I'm not in charge.

Something like they did on Jackson Blvd in Christopher Columbus Park would have been perfect.

segments.name: Grand Avenue Safety Improvements, Chicago to Damen
segments.description: Complete Streets safety improvements have been installed on Grand Avenue between Chicago Avenue and Damen Avenue to make the street safer and more inviting for everyone  no matter how you get around  and improve neighborhood access to local businesses. Construction is upcoming on the next segment of the project  Grand Avenue from Damen Avenue to Ogden Avenue.

segments.name: Grand Avenue Safety Improvements, Damen to Ogden
segments.description: Complete Streets safety improvements have been installed on Grand Avenue between Chicago Avenue and Damen Avenue to make the street safer and more inviting for everyone  no matter how you get around  and improve neighborhood access to local businesses. Construction is upcoming on the next segment of the project  Grand Avenue from Damen Avenue to Ogden Avenue.

CDOT is implementing traffic calming on Granville, including converting parts of the street to one-way with counterflow bicycle lanes. It's not perfect but it's an improvement over what is currently there, and some sections will have concrete protection, so it qualifies for the map.

One-way cycle tracks in each direction. Existed before 2021, but was upgraded and expanded with fresh paint and better barriers sometime before 2024 (further specification needed).
WARNING: There are sections of the route that are sub-par and do not include protection.

segments.name: Harrison to Flournoy
segments.description: This is listed on the official map, but streetview says it doesn't exist.

segments.name: Lexington to Arthington
segments.description: Awaiting visual confirmation of changes. As of September 2024, the bike lane was unprotected and frequently blocked by parked cars.

segments.name: Grenshaw to Roosevelt
segments.description: Awaiting visual confirmation of changes. As of September 2024, the bike lane was unprotected and frequently blocked by parked cars.

segments.name: North Ave to Grand Ave
segments.completion: Construction start in 2025, end date unknown

segments.name: 31st to Garfield
segments.description:
One-way protected bike lane included as part of a resurfacing project. Original project would only go from 31st to 35th, but new plan will extend the bicycle lane all the way to Garfield (55th) street.

New concrete curbs and paint.

segments.name: Christopher Columbus Park
segments.description:
Note that this is not a trail path, but a fully-separated bicycle lane on a road that runs through the park. Should there be a road that runs through a park? Probably not. But at least there's a nice bike lane.

This is a great model for how to handle bus stops and bike lanes together.

segments.name: Laflin to Halsted
segments.description: For some inconceivable reason, they made this a one-way bike lane. Only goes west to east.

segments.name: 28th to Archer
segments.description:
Parking-protected

Construction Update (12/25/2025)
- Concrete & asphalt work: Complete
- Pavement Striping: Anticipated completion by first week of January
- Precast Concrete Curbs for Bike Lanes: Anticipated completion by second week of January
- Signs & Flexible Delineators: Anticipated to begin the last week of December. Anticipated duration of 2-3 weeks.
- Impact Attenuator installation at viaduct south of W 31st Street: Scheduled installation around mid-January 2026.

segments.name: Damen to N Pine Ave
segments.description: Protection only in the eastbound direction. Watch out for cars going west. Has some concrete, but mostly bollards, so it's still considered a RIPBL.

segments.name: Berwyn to Diversey
segments.description:
• 20mph speed limit
  • Speed humps
  • Curb extensions
  • Painted contraflow bike lane

name: Leland Neighborhood Greenway
description:
• 20mph speed limit
  • Speed humps
  • Curb extensions
  • Painted contraflow bike lane

segments.name: Irving Park to Belmont
segments.description: Since installation, CDOT has recorded a 50% increase in cycling volumes, as well as 97% compliance with speed limits.

Note: There is no protection across the bridge, so I have left the bridge off of the map. They do use sturdier barriers and posts though, they're the kind that are only flexible in one direction for emergency vehicles.
Marked as a greenway, although there isn't any physical infrastructure. Considering removing from the map.

links.name: Project Website, Campbell to North Avenue

segments.name: Roosevelt to Kedzie
segments.description: CDOT has been awarded a $3 million grant from the the Illinois Transportation Enhancement Program to "convert excess vehicle space to off-street bike alnes, pedestrian refuge islands, bump-outs and bus-stop improvements". No further information about the project is currently available.
Fully reconstructed bicycle lane with concrete curbs.

segments.name: Ravenswood to Western
segments.description:
Proposed, not yet in planning.

Mentioned during the 2025 40th Ward Development and Infrastructure Town Hall, as part of the Far North Side Bicycle Network Plan.

links.name: 40th Ward Development and Infrastructure Town Hall Summary

segments.description: Really, really bad protection. It's buffered, so that's good, but there are only a few posts and no concrete or barriers at all.

segments.name: Chicago Avenue to Ingleside
segments.description: Two-way cycletrack extending through the heart of Evanston's Northwestern University campus, connecting to the Chicago Avenue bike lane to go all the way to Davis (and soon to the Chicago 49th Ward border at Howard).
Some concrete, mostly posts.
NOTE: Only has protection in northbound direction!

segments.name: 9th to Roosevelt
segments.description: No recent streetview :( they weren't there as of 2021

segments.name: Augusta to Milwaukee
segments.description: Receiving upgrades in 2025, including one-way conversion for car traffic, street resurfacing, curb ramp replacements, and gutter replacements.

segments.name: Woodlawn
segments.description: Marking this as incomplete because it wasn't done as of September 2024 and I haven't been down to check. If you live near this bike lane and can confirm that it exists, send me a message with the Contact button at the top of this page.
